results.title: Mondo New York
results.creator_credit: International Harmony Productions, Stuart Shapiro and Harvey Keith
results.brief_description: A young woman wanders the clubs and streets of New York City in the mid 1980s in search of entertainment or just to seek out the freaks. She sees avant-garde style musicians, spoken word performances, junkies, sadomasochistic shows and comedians of the era. Not a narrative but more a compilation of performances, ‘Mondo New York’ is a glimpse of a moment in time, when the punk ethos of ‘shocking behaviour’ and being ‘alternative’ were celebrated in the arts/under world. Some scenes and language may offend and some animals ARE harmed in the making of this picture. Performers featured include: Lydia Lunch, Joey Arias, Rick Aviles, Charlie Barnett, Joe Coleman, Phoebe Legre and Ann Magnuson.

results.title: Mondo Lugosi: a vampire's scrapbook
results.brief_description: A compilation of movie trailers and excerpts from many of Bela Lugosi’s horror films dating from the 1930s to the late 1940s. Born Bela Ferenc Dezso Blasko on 20 October 1882 in Lugos, Hungary, Lugosi began his acting career on stage performing with the Budapest Academy of Theatrical Arts and as a leading actor with Hungary’s Royal National Theatre. By 1920 Lugosi had moved across to Germany where he began appearing in films. He emigrated to America in 1921 playing bit parts in obscure films until finally in 1931 he broke into the Hollywood scene, cast in the title role of the horror film, “Dracula”. Numerous other films of similar genre followed, including “Murders in the Rue Morgue” (1932), “The Invisible ray” (1936), “The Wolf man” (1941), “The Ghost of Frankenstein” (1942), “Frankenstein meets the Wolf Man” (1942) and “The Body snatcher” (1945). Trailers of these films, along with interviews and appearances by Lugosi on American television programs “Tribute to a star” and “You asked for it” are contained in this video. Includes scenes with Boris Karloff, Frances Drake, Claude Rains, Betty Boop and many other stars of the time.

results.title: Monarch butterfly story
results.brief_description: Portrays the four stages in the life cycle of the Monarch butterfly. Close-up photography depicts the Monarch laying its eggs, and shows the caterpillar eating its way out of the egg, feeding, moulting, forming its chrysalis, and emerging as a butterfly.

results.title: Mona Lisa descending a staircase
results.creator_credit: Pyramid Film and Video, American Film Institute, National Endowment for the Arts and Joan C. Gratz
results.brief_description: Using the innovative technique of clay painting, artist and filmmaker Joan Gratz takes the viewer on an entertaining and colourful journey through the development of Modern Art. Starting with the brilliant landscapes and haunting self-portraits of impressionism, “Mona Lisa descending a staircase” moves through cubism and surrealism, then finishes with vibrant images of contemporary pop art and hyper-realism. Featuring some 55 paintings and 35 artists from Van Gogh to Warhol, the video shifts seamlessly from image to image to make this artistic presentation as emotionally gripping as it is visually fascinating.

results.title: Mona Lisa
results.creator_credit: HandMade Films, Palace Pictures, Patrick Cassavetti, Stephen Woolley and Neil Jordan
results.brief_description: Bob Hoskins plays a small-time con, just out of prison, who is delivering porn videos for a living. He gets a job as a minder to call-girl, Simone, (Cathy Tyson) and soon finds he is falling in love with her and assisting her to find her friend, Cathy, a young prostitute who has disappeared. A stylish film-noir set in contemporary London, “Mona Lisa” is also a challenging film about honour, responsibility and compassion in a society that is decaying and cruel. Cast also includes Michael Caine and Robbie Coltrane.

results.title: Mon oncle Antoine
results.creator_credit: Gendon Films, ONF | NFB, Marc Beaudet and Claude Jutra
results.brief_description: There was a time when the general store was the crossroads of life, a place where a boy could learn all he needed for the way ahead - especially when his uncle was the storekeeper, and also the undertaker, and the nephew often called upon to lend a hand. This film recalls such a store in a village in the asbestos mining area of Quebec in the early 1940s. The film presents a hundred-and-one vignettes of village life - all the bitter-sweet nostalgia with which a man might remember the events that thrust him into manhood. Mon oncle Antoine is about a Quebec that makes no headlines but reflects the whole of life, the ebb and flow of hope and despair that might be in anyone’s memory. (Awards: Fifteen awards including Moscow; Chicago; Toronto) In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Mon homme
results.creator_credit: Les Films Alain Sarde, Plateau A, Studio Images 2, Canal+, Alain Sarde and Bertrand Blier
results.brief_description: This darkly humorous, erotic drama centres on Marie, an independent prostitute with a heart of gold. After rescuing a down-and-out homeless man one night, she falls in love with him and invites him to be her pimp. Soon he starts recruiting other women - the inexperience of one of the new recruits landing them all in jail. Discovering her lover’s duplicity, Marie decides to reform. In French with English subtitles. Cast includes Anouk Grinberg, Gerard Lanvin, Valeria Bruni-Tedeschi and Olivier Martinez. Winner of the Silver Bear Best Actress award at the Berlin Film Festival 1996.

results.title: Momotaro, the peach boy
results.brief_description: Japanese animated puppet version of a fairy story. An old couple find a baby boy in a peach and bring him up as their own son. He becomes the strongest boy in the village, and is able to save some villagers who are kidnapped by demons.
results.description: Japanese animated puppet version of a fairy story. An old couple find a baby boy in a peach and bring him up as their own son. He becomes the strongest boy in the village, and is able to save some villagers who are kidnapped by demons.

results.title: Mommie dearest
results.creator_credit: Paramount Pictures, Frank Yablans Productions, Frank Yablan and Frank Perry
results.brief_description: Faye Dunaway stars as screen legend Joan Crawford in this biographical feature about Joan’s life from her adopted daughter’s point of view. Joan Crawford was a powerful star produced by the Hollywood Studio System but as the old saying goes, money can’t buy happiness and she yearned to be a mother. As a single woman she adopted children but her dependence on alcohol led to the alleged abuse of the children and her personality at home is revealed to be controlling and overbearing. Script is based on the tell-all novel “Mommie Dearest” by Christina Crawford. Also stars Diana Scarwid as the older Christina.

results.title: Momma don't allow
results.creator_credit: BFI, Karel Reisz and Tony Richardson
results.brief_description: One of the ‘Free Cinema’ films produced with the assistance of the British Film Institute Experimental Production Fund, established to encourage the production of films of an experimental or original nature. It was photographed on nine Saturday evenings at Art and Viv Sanders’ ‘Wood Green Jazz Club’ in ‘The Fishmonger’s Arms’. It was shot with the co-operation of the club’s members and was made cheaply on 16mm film with single-track sound transferred from tape recordings. Unhampered by sponsors, the makers of this film have been free to capture and admire the freedom, exuberance and vitality of the Jazz Club. These suburban clubs were run for and by enthusiasts; their atmosphere was not whipped up by promoters but created by the London teenagers who evolved their own free styles of dancing and created their own world of relaxation and enjoyment. Appearing in this film are members of ‘The Chris Barber Band’, Chris Barber, Pat Halcox, Lonnie Donegan, Monty Sunshine, Ron Bowden, Jim Bray and Ottilie Patterson.
